message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and signs strongly suggest hypoparathyroidism, which can occur after thyroidectomy with central neck dissection due to inadvertent removal or injury of the parathyroid glands. This leads to decreased calcium levels in the blood and subsequent neuromuscular and cardiovascular symptoms. Vitamin D and ionic calcium supplementation can help prevent and treat hypoparathyroidism in this setting. Anticonvulsants and magnesium sulfate may be used to treat seizures associated with hypocalcemia, but do not prevent hypocalcemia. Potassium supplementation is not indicated in this case, as potassium levels are already normal.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, physical examination findings, and laboratory results suggest that the patient is experiencing hypocalcemia due to parathyroid gland injury during her thyroidectomy. Therefore, administration of Vitamin D and ionic calcium prior to and 2 weeks after the operation could prevent the patient's condition. Anticonvulsants are not effective in treating hypocalcemia, magnesium sulfate is used to treat magnesium deficiency, and potassium supplementation is not helpful in treating hypocalcemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest hypocalcemia caused by damage to the parathyroid glands during the thyroidectomy. Vitamin D and ionic calcium supplementation can prevent and treat hypocalcemia in this case. Anticonvulsants and magnesium sulfate are not indicated, and potassium supplementation is not necessary as the patient's potassium level is within normal range.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing symptoms of hypocalcemia, which can occur as a result of thyroid surgery. The administration of vitamin D and ionic calcium prior to and after the operation can prevent the patient’s condition. Anticonvulsants and potassium supplementation are not appropriate treatments for hypocalcemia, and magnesium sulfate may worsen the patient’s hypermagnesemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is showing signs of hypocalcemia, which is a common complication after thyroidectomy due to accidental injury to or removal of the parathyroid glands. Vitamin D and ionic calcium supplementation can help prevent and treat hypocalcemia in these patients. Anticonvulsants and potassium supplementation are not indicated for this condition. Magnesium sulfate may be used intraoperatively to prevent arrhythmias but would not prevent hypocalcemia.

Magnesium sulfate can be used to prevent or treat hypomagnesemia, but it is not the first-line treatment for hypocalcemia.
